data.text: Are Decathlon Panniers Suitable for Long-Distance Touring?

Hi , I wanted to buy these rear trunk panniers from Decathlon for a few days to days tour.In the description they write these are for asphalt only and not suitable for touring,even though these are water resistant.Anyone have experience with these what are possible risks If I still go with these panniers and why they might not be suitable for touring?
I've seen them before, they are not adapted: they jump, they move... the fixation is not top notch
data.author: Pedro LaSangr

data.text: If they fit your bike & their waterproof they will work for you. Simple.
data.author: Taniya Morris

data.text: I guess the biggest issue might be that they will come loose/flap about. I can't see on the picture, but I'm assuming on the back they'll have a small hook that hooks around the frame. But if you ride over bumpy ground, they will come loose all the time. But you can definitely try if you think they'd be okay.
data.author: Charlotte Kramer

data.text: These bags are rated for 7kg max per bag. Touring you would most likely exceed that. If you are going off road, then jolting will greatly increase the load on the seams and mounting points. Looking at the construction, it does not appear to be super strong, and that method of seam construction may see seams open up. The velcro straps that attach the panniers to the bike may not hold them down if you bounce, and the panniers could fly off the rack. By comparison the Decathlon Elops500 waterproof pannier has a much more secure mounting mechanism. The risk using these bags looks like they would be ripping the mounting hooks out oft the back of the bags and burst seams. I have used bags like this for commuting and shopping, which they do well, but maybe not up to the rigours of touring. Yes, you could tour with them, but Decathlon's exceptional warantee service suggests that they know the limits of their products, and if they don't suggest you use them for touring, then they might just have a point.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: exellent explanation
data.author: Harald Hartman

data.text: I expect you could try to make the mounting scheme stronger...
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text:
Try to check this https://www.tailfin.cc/discipline/road/?v=ea8a1a99f6c9
Road/Touring - Tailfin Cycling
tailfin.cc
data.author: Benny V. De Guzman

data.text: Personally, I'd look for used "real" touring bags in your local classified ads, or to borrow from a friend for a few days. But to be honest, a lot can be achieved with sub-ideal gear. You could ask the staff if you can carry them over to a decathlon bike in the store, and see for yourself how well they hold when you shake them. Let's also look at real risk: On the front wheel, the danger of something breaking is much more severe than on the back, because if s.th. blocks your front wheel, you will fly over the handlebar. On the back wheel, it can be dangerous when you are driving directly next to heavy traffic, but usually much less dangerous than when something happens near the front wheel. So this is risk to you, bike, car drivers. Another risk may be that the bag falls off and s.o. riding right behind you drives over it and falls. Then let's look at risk for your belongings. In the worst case, you will lose some t-shirts. Perhaps carry a small shopping bag in case something really breaks, so you don't stand there with a hand full of laundry. But to be honest, probably they will hold up for your weekend tour. But if you like it, you would buy something better again.
data.author: Matthias Tango

data.text: Decathlon make some proper touring panniers which are pretty good
data.author: Brendan Payne

data.text: Why would you go for them when the manufacturer specifically states that they're not suitable for touring?
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: Don't have a balance, and not useful
data.author: Turgay Kele≈ü

data.text: try
data.author: Robert Mac

data.text: From what I can see, everything looks like it's made with cloth and are only kept in place with gravity. If you jostle them enough, I'm certain the seams will give. All of my panniers HOOK onto the cargo rack with polyethylene or metal hooks and the mounting hardware is screwed into plastic backing to give the cloth bags some structure.
data.author: Louie Garcia

data.text: " water resistant" has no place in my bike touring repertoire. Panniers must be water proof unless you plan on plastic bagging all the contents. I've been through some monsoon rain events and there's nothing like putting on some dry clothes when you get to your destination.
data.author: Peter Sheridan

data.text: They look exactly like the ones my husband uses, which came from Decathlon. We go off-road all the time and we jam them full. We have used them for several tours and we reckon they are great because you just whip open that velcro top and everything inside is super easily-accessible.
data.author: Cath Wood

data.text: Having said that, the way they are attached is by a hook over the rack, so there have been times off-road when one side has jumped off the frame. Nothing happens, it just sits a bit awkwardly until you stop and flick it back on. Doesn't happen often enough for us to consider it a problem.
data.author: Cath Wood

data.text: As Cath said, they are bullet proof and the above is the only issue we have encountered, apart from overloading then and struggling to move! They can carry a good volume....
data.author: Cam Wood

data.text: Hm
data.author: Jonathan Gregore

data.text: I always wondered about these? Would having just one on the left throw the balance off? Could I still hit light trails and Some gnarly ones too?
data.author: Sheik Sheik

data.text: I used a similar type of bags that came on my Mongoose Envoy. They were supposed to be for riding around town. I put construction trash liners in each for water proof and wrapped a good thick bungee cord around from top to bottom to keep it from bouncing around and opening up. They are not especially "aero". There's also a danger of wanting to pack more since they are big bags. At the end of the day, thousands of miles later, they still work though it is a different brand.
data.author: Nicholas Lafferty

data.text: Panniers should be Water proof...other wise any bag which can be hooked to your carrier is fine.... another important is the capacity...that differs from person to person... journey length... period...
data.author: Bharat Ketkar

data.text: Not very strong spend a bit more get some ortlieb 100 percent waterproof bags
data.author: Mark Hepworth

data.text: A bag is a bag. If you can attach it well to your bike, you'll be OK. They look like they sling over a rear rack, so no worries, there - just make sure they don't get caught up in the rear wheel. Wrap your clothes in plastic shopping bags to keep them dry and they'll be just fine in these panniers. Don't overload them to carry 25kg or expand for items shaped unlike the bags' volume and I expect you won't have problems.
data.author: Rob Rushworth

data.text: We bought some from Amazon. They cost ¬£16 and are still going strong after 3 bike tours. If you don‚Äôt fill them to bursting I‚Äôm sure those will be ok
data.author: Hazel Baker

data.text: Attachimg lower parts of the bags can be usefull so they jump with the bike
data.author: Uros Lebar

data.text: Used mine from Germany to Austria an carried weight
data.author: Frogs Gray
